1.text: Canst thou draw out leviathan with a fish hook? or press down his tongue with a cord?

2.text: Canst thou put a rope into his nose? or pierce his jaw through with a hook?

3.text: Will he make many supplications unto thee? or will he speak soft words unto thee?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with thee, that thou shouldest take him for a servant for ever?

5.text: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

6.text: Shall the bands of fishermen make traffic of him? shall they part him among the merchants?

7.text: Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons, or his head with fish spears?

8.text: Lay thine hand upon him; remember the battle, and do so no more.

9.text: Behold, the hope of him is in vain: shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?

10.text: None is so fierce that he dare stir him up: who then is he that can stand before me?

11.text: Who hath first given unto me, that I should repay him? whatsoever is under the whole heaven is mine.

12.text: I will not keep silence concerning his limbs, nor his mighty strength, nor his comely proportion.

13.text: Who can strip off his outer garment? who shall come within his double bridle?

14.text: Who can open the doors of his face? round about his teeth is terror.

15.text: His strong scales are his pride, shut up together as with a close seal.

16.text: One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.

17.text: They are joined one to another; they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.

18.text: His neesings flash forth light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.

19.text: Out of his mouth go burning torches, and sparks of fire leap forth.

20.text: Out of his nostrils a smoke goeth, as of a seething pot and burning rushes.

21.text: His breath kindleth coals, and a flame goeth forth from his mouth.

22.text: In his neck abideth strength, and terror danceth before him.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are firm upon him; they cannot be moved.

24.text: His heart is as firm as a stone; yea, firm as the nether millstone.

25.text: When he raiseth himself up, the mighty are afraid: by reason of consternation they are beside themselves.

26.text: If one lay at him with the sword, it cannot avail; nor the spear, the dart, nor the pointed shaft.

27.text: He counteth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.

28.text: The arrow cannot make him flee: slingstones are turned with him into stubble.

29.text: Clubs are counted as stubble: he laugheth at the rushing of the javelin.

30.text: His underparts are like sharp potsherds: he spreadeth as it were a threshing wain upon the mire.

31.text: He maketh the deep to boil like a pot: he maketh the sea like ointment.

32.text: He maketh a path to shine after him; one would think the deep to be hoary.

33.text: Upon earth there is not his like, that is made without fear.

34.text: He beholdeth every thing that is high: he is king over all the sons of pride.
